III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program Statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
1

(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff 1 is in a relationship with Supervisor who continues to delete
video footage of events.
Supervisor also has staff re-write incident reports.
Supervisor brought in weed vapes and pens for two youth on an
unknown date.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 4/14/25. Complainant
did not provide any additional information.
Youth E was interviewed on 4/14/25 face-to-face at his current
placement along with MDHHS Specialist. Youth E denied having
issues or concerns with staff at the facility other than one staff who
was terminated while he was there. Youth E reported Supervisor
had given him vape pens and weed edibles multiple times. Youth
E reported Supervisor gave him potato chips that were laced with
weed. Youth E reported these items were also given to Youth A.
Youth E denied any other youth being given these items. Youth E
denied having concerns about Supervisor. Youth E denied having
concerns with Staff 1.
Youth C was interviewed on 4/23/25 face-to-face at his school
along with MDHHS Specialist. Youth C denied having concerns
with any staff at the facility during his time placed there. Youth C
denied Supervisor ever giving him or any other youth vape pens,
weed pens, or edibles. Youth C reported liking Staff 1 and not
having any concerns with him. Youth C denied awareness of Staff
1 being in a relationship with anyone else who worked at the
facility.
Supervisor was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 4/16/25
along with MDHHS Specialist. Supervisor denied having an
inappropriate or romantic relationship with any staff at the facility
including Staff 1. Supervisor denied altering incident reports and
denied directing staff to alter incident reports. Supervisor reported
incident reports may require additional detail, and she gives
feedback when appropriate. Supervisor denied deleting camera
footage further stating that she would have no ability to do so.
Supervisor denied covering for Staff 1 or any other staff following
any incidents at the facility. Supervisor denied bringing weed
vapes or pens to the facility and denied giving weed vapes or
2

pens to any youth. Supervisor denied bringing in and giving any
youth snacks, chips, or edibles.
Youth A and Youth B were interviewed separately at the facility
face-to-face on 4/16/25 along with MDHHS Specialist. Youth A
and Youth B both denied any staff including Supervisor giving
them, or any other youth weed pens, vapes, or edibles. Youth A
and Youth B denied having concerns with Staff 1, stating that Staff
1 is their favorite staff. Youth A and Youth B denied having any
concerns with Supervisor.
Staff 1 was interviewed at the facility face-to-face on 5/6/25 along
with MDHHS Specialist. Staff 1 denied ever being instructed to
rewrite an incident report or change details in an incident report
and reported he has never done either. Staff 1 denied being in a
relationship of any kind with Supervisor or that Supervisor deletes
camera footage for any reason. Staff 1 denied knowledge or
witnessing Supervisor or any other employee provide weed pens,
weed vapes, or edibles to any youth at the facility.
Staff 2 was interviewed at the facility face-to-face on 5/6/25 along
with MDHHS Specialist. Staff 2 denied witnessing or having
knowledge of any supervisor or staff giving youth weed pens,
vapes, or edibles. Staff 2 denied any knowledge of any employees
at the facility engaging in a romantic relationship, including
Supervisor and Staff 1. Staff 2 denied knowledge of Supervisor or
any other staff rewriting or changing incident reports or deleting
camera footage. Staff 2 denied any concerns with Supervisor or
Staff 1.
Youth D was interviewed at the facility face-to-face on 5/6/25
along with MDHHS Specialist. Youth D denied having concerns
with Supervisor or Staff 1. Youth D denied Supervisor giving youth
anything they are not supposed to have. Youth D reported not
seeing Staff 1 for a long time.
Documents reviewed:
• Staff 1’s employee file contains 2 disciplinary actions,
unrelated to this investigation. Staff 1’s training log reflects
39 hours of completed training including on topics of
incident report writing and new hire orientation.
• Supervisor’s employee file contains 2 disciplinary actions,
unrelated to this investigation. Supervisor’s training record
includes 164 hours of training since 1/27/2023. Training
records include completed training on incident reporting.
• Workplace Relationships/Nepotism Policy prohibits
superior/subordinate relationships.
3

• Employee Standards of Conduct Policy prohibits
falsification, omission, or misrepresentation of any records
and that employees are expected to be honest and
cooperative in all job-related responsibilities.
• Employee Handbook, ethical behavior section, page 16
states it is prohibited to bring in any item for a client that is
not approved by your immediate supervisor.
• Critical Incident Response and Reporting Policy states staff
managing the incident are responsible for completion of the
incident report which is then reviewed by the shift
supervisor.
• Email authored by Chief Administrator states Supervisor
does not have access/ability to delete camera footage as
the facility utilizes a 3rd party company. Email states that
there is no history of concern with Supervisor as it pertains
to incident reporting.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as per interviews conducted,
there is no evidence to support any of the allegations. All staff and
youth, except for Youth E, denied youth have been given weed
pens, vapes, or edibles by Supervisor or any other employees.
Staff interviews denied Supervisor providing school transportation
to youth Supervisor and Staff 1 denied being in a relationship and
no other staff acknowledged a relationship between Supervisor
and Staff 1. Tampering with incident reports and camera footage
were denied by all staff, and Chief Administrator reported
Supervisor does not have the ability to delete camera footage.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & R 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not
limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or
pushing a youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A few months ago, Supervisor slapped Youth A because he was
acting up and this resulted in two black eyes.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 4/14/25. Complainant
did not provide any additional information.
Youth E was interviewed on 4/14/25 face-to-face at his current
placement along with MDHHS Specialist. Youth E denied having
4

concerns about Supervisor. After being prompted it was alleged
Supervisor slapped a youth in the van on the way to school, Youth
E replied, “oh yeah, I saw Supervisor slap Youth C on the way to
school”, but did not provide any other details.
Youth C was interviewed on 4/23/25 face-to-face at his school
along with MDHHS Specialist. Youth C denied ever witnessing
any staff hit any youth. Youth C denied that Supervisor ever
provided youth transportation to school. Youth C reported Youth B
may have had a black eye before but was not sure where he got it
and did not ask about it.
Supervisor was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 4/16/25
along with MDHHS Specialist. Supervisor denied striking Youth A
at any time and denied giving Youth A any black eyes. Supervisor
denied providing transportation to school for any youth at any
time. Supervisor denied observing Youth A with black eyes since
he has been placed at the facility.
Youth A was interviewed at the facility face-to-face on 4/16/25
along with MDHHS Specialist. Youth A denied being hit in the face
or anywhere else by Supervisor at any time. Youth A denied
Supervisor ever transporting him to school. Youth A denied ever
having two black eyes or one back eye while at the facility. Youth
A denied having any concerns with Supervisor.
Youth B was interviewed at the facility face-to-face on 4/16/25
along with MDHHS Specialist. Youth B denied being aware of
Supervisor hitting Youth A or hitting any other youth at the facility.
Youth B denied Supervisor transporting youth to school. Youth B
denied seeing Youth A with any black eyes.
Staff 1 was interviewed at the facility face-to-face on 5/6/25 along
with MDHHS Specialist. Staff 1 denied knowledge of Supervisor
hitting Youth A or any other youth at any time. Staff 1 reported not
being aware if Supervisor provides transportation to school.
Staff 2 was interviewed at the facility face-to-face on 5/6/25 along
with MDHHS Specialist. Staff 2 denied knowledge of Youth A
having black eyes or being hit by any supervisor or staff. Staff
denied knowledge of Supervisor providing any transportation to
any youth.
Youth D was interviewed at the facility face-to-face on 5/6/25
along with MDHHS Specialist. Youth D denied seeing Youth A
with any black eyes. Youth D did not know if Supervisor provides
transportation to school.
5

Documents reviewed:
• Supervisor’s employee file contains 2 disciplinary actions,
unrelated to this investigation. Supervisor’s training record
includes 164 hours of training since 1/27/2023. Training
records include completed training on appropriate
behavioral management.
• Prohibited Interventions Policy prohibits use of physical
discipline.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as per interviews conducted, all
youth and staff, except Youth E, denied Youth A or any other
youth were struck in the face by Supervisor. Further, it was denied
Supervisor provides transportation to school as Youth E alleged.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
